ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Multivariable calculus
Calculus knowledge

I recovered my skills with calculus (after a yearlong hiatus for AP Stats senior year of high school), improved my understanding of vectors, learning how to take double integrals, calculate surface areas and integrals, and learned the Green, Stokes, and Divergence theoremswhat I expected, with perhaps more vectors than I anticipated.
I gained knowledge about multivariable calculus, including but not limited to vector fields, double and triple integrals, and polar, cylindrical, and spherical coordinate systems.
A basic understanding of multivariable calculus, visualizing shapes/surfaces in 3D
I learned to interpret multivariable functions. I also learned to make connections from single-variable calculus to the topic learned in multivariable calculus.
I learned multivariable calculus. More specifically, I learned all of the theorems needed to evaluate functions over lines, surfaces, and solids, and how all of these theorems are connected.

I feel like taking this course actually taught me what math is. Previously I always felt like I was just kind of going through the motions and plugging in equations, but this course forced me to actually understand what I was doing so I could think deeply about the problems and apply what I learned.
Multivariable calculus (vector integrals, double and triple integrals, Fundamental theorems of Calculus)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The instructor was very difficult to understand and painfully boring
Strong course

The problem sets align well with the course content, though we were behind by the end, especially with the problem set due during reading week. The course does a solid job of building upon itself and, by the final week, everything fits together. Perhaps more foreshadowing of this would have been better, though I did enjoy the explanation of why we were learning triple integrals (the Divergence theorem) before we spent time on the topic.

More review would have improved the course around the midterms; we would be two weeks ahead in terms of content in a lecture and then take the midterm that evening.
The lecture videos for the course on canvas were helpful for learning the information. I wish they reduced the amount of tedious calculation in the psets.

This course touched on a broad variety of topics relating to multivariable calculus; in addition, connections with topics in physics were made. There were a lot of resources (e.g. office hours, practice problems, review sessions, peer tutoring) to supplement student learning.

The videos provided before each class were very helpful in learning the material. I also liked how there were lots of practice problems and practice exams available to help students for midterms and the finals. I don't have any complaints.

I had to rely more on videos than I probably would've liked to, but that might just be due to the nature of the content. Not a fan of having PSETs due the week of a test. Peer Tutors were very good. PSETs are much harder than the tests so they prepare you well.

This course requires you to learn the content 3 times - once by watching videos, once by reading the textbook, and once in class. This can be helpful (for me, for example; I have auditory processing issues so reading the book is my best way of learning), but it also seems redundant and encourages students to not come to class.
Section is often a repetition of the videos and textbook and is often not helpful. Should be replaced with group work or in person P-Sets.

A strength of the course is the amount of supplemental resources to help you if you need more help outside of class like peer tutoring, Ximera, coaching sessions, and pre-class videos. However, I'd say the structure of the class in person was a weakness. The pre-class videos were supposed to just be a primer for class where we would learn the information and then do group work. However, we didn't do group work that often, and the class didn't really go over the information in-depth, so the pre-class videos became a primary source of my knowledge of the course material. However, it sounds like this experience differed based on section. I feel like more class time could have been dedicated to working through problems similar to those seen on the psets and exams because class problems were often pretty straightforward, but then pset questions would expand on these in ways we hadn't really gone over.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. The math department is sadistic and very poor at teaching.
If they want calculus knowledge, they should take it.
I would. It's an essential step for physics (why I was interested) and the ideal next step for students who did well in AP Calculus BC (again, speaking from my own experience).
Yes - Provides a good foundational understanding of multivariable calc.
I would recommend this course to any students looking to pursue a STEM major; it is helpful for many types of sciences (e.g. physics and chemistry).
I would recommend it for a student who has this course as a major requirement.
Yeah sure. A good course to learn new things. However it is hard so if you really just want to learn stuff and aren't required to take it you could watch math videos.
I only took it for Physics 260- if you have to, take it, its an effective course. If not, though, its not worth it.
Yes, it can feel daunting at times but overall was quite interesting and the connections to physics sparked interest in further math and physics.
If you're interested in calculus or need it as a pre-req then yes, but I wouldn't recommend if it's not needed as a requirement.
